revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name=61st Rifle Corps |image= |caption= |country=[[Soviet Union]] |allegiance= |type=Infantry |branch=[[Red Army]] |dates= First formation: 1939–41
Second formation: 1943–45 |specialization= |command_structure=[[Western Front (Soviet Union)|Western Front]] 1941,
[[Western Front (Soviet Union)|Western Front]] 1943,
[[1st Belorussian Front]] 1944–45 |size= |garrison= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles=[[World War II]] *[[Battle of Smolensk (1941)]] *[[Battle of Smolensk (1943)]] * [[Lublin–Brest Offensive]] * [[Battle of Berlin]] |battle_honours=Radom (Second formation) |notable_commanders= Major General [[Fyodor Bakunin]] (1941)
Lt. General [[Ivan Grigorievsky]] (1944–45) |anniversaries= }} The '''61st Rifle Corps''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: 61-й стрелковый корпус ''61-y strelkovy korpus '') was a [[Red Army]] [[Rifle corps (Soviet Union)|infantry corps]] during [[World War II]], formed twice. The 61st Rifle Corps was formed firmed in Tula during September 1939. After Operation Barbarossa, it was transferred to the front in Belarus and fought in the [[Battle of Smolensk (1941)|Battle of Smolensk]]. After suffering heavy losses at Smolensk, it was disbanded in early August 1941. Reformed in spring 1943, the corps fought in [[Operation Kutuzov]], the [[Lublin–Brest Offensive]] and the [[Berlin Offensive]]. The corps was disbanded after the end of the war in summer 1945. == First formation == The corps was formed in September 1939.{{Cite web|title = Стрелковые и воздушно-десантные корпуса РККА 1941–1945 гг.|url = http://www.soldat.ru/spravka/korpusa_rkka/table1.html |website = |trans-title = The infantry and airborne corps of the Red Army, 1941–1945.}} It was stationed near [[Tula, Russia|Tula]]. The corps was commanded by Major General [[Fyodor Bakunin]] from April 1940.{{Cite web|title = Biography of Major-General Fedor Alekseevich Bakunin – (Source: Courtesy of Ilya Mukhin) – (Федор Алексеевич Бакунин) (1898–1984), Soviet Union|url = http://generals.dk/general/Bakunin/Fedor_Alekseevich/Soviet_Union.html|website = generals.dk|access-date = 2016-02-10}} The corps began the war as part of the [[20th Army (Soviet Union)|20th Army]]. After the beginning of the war, it was moved to Belarus south of [[Mogilev]] and took defensive positions in the area of [[Škłoŭ|Škłou]], [[Mogilev]] and [[Bykhaw]].{{Cite web|title = Стрелковые 61–80 {{!}}|url = http://myfront.in.ua/krasnaya-armiya/korpusa/strelkovye-61-80.html|website = myfront.in.ua|access-date = 2016-02-10|language = Russian|trans-title = Rifle 61–80}} In June 1941, the corps fought in the [[Battle of Smolensk (1941)|Battle of Smolensk]]. During the battle, it [[Siege of Mogilev|defended]] Mogilev and fought for Smolensk. On 1 July, it was composed of the [[18th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|18th]], [[110th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|110th]] and [[172nd Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|172nd Rifle Divisions]].{{Cite book|title = Barbarossa Derailed: The German Advance to Smolensk, the Encirclement Battle, and the First and Second Soviet Counteroffensives, 10 July – 24 August 1941|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=SDfInc6Gb40C|publisher = Casemate Publishers|date = 2010-01-01|isbn = 978-1-906033-72-9|language = en|first = David M.|last = Glantz|page = 598 |ref=harv}} On 3 July, the vanguard of the [[2nd Panzer Army]] reached the approaches to Mogilev and fought with the 95–96 corps. On 7 July 1941, it was composed of the [[53rd Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|53rd]], 110th and 172nd Rifle Divisions. On the same day, the division moved to a defensive line on the banks of the Dnieper north of Mogilev. The new positions were on the line of [[Shkloŭ]], Mogilev and [[Buinichi]]. Around this time, the corps was subordinated to the [[13th Army (Soviet Union)|13th Army]]. On 10 July, the [[2nd SS Panzer Division Das Reich]] of [[Heinrich von Vietinghoff]]'s [[XXXXVI Motorized Corps]] advanced to the Dnieper in the Mogilev area. [[10th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|10th Panzer Division]] also advanced to the river in the Shklov area. The 10th Panzer Division soon crossed the Dnieper and routed the corps' 53rd Rifle Division, capturing a bridgehead.{{Sfn|Glantz|2010|pp = 95–96}} Troops of the 61st Rifle Corps, [[20th Mechanized Corps (Soviet Union)|20th Mechanized Corps]] and [[4th Airborne Corps (Soviet Union)|4th Airborne Corps]] were pushed back by the German advances. On 13 July, corps commander Bakunin was ordered to attack the 10th Panzer Division's bridgehead using the 110th Rifle Division and the 20th Mechanized Corps. The 20th Mechanized Corps was not equipped with tanks and did not have time to concentrate forces. As a result, the attack was repulsed. By 15 July, Mogilev was loosely encircled. It was now defended by the 61st Rifle Corps, most of the [[20th Rifle Corps]], remnants of the [[148th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|148th]] and [[187th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|187th Rifle Divisions]], the 1st Motor Rifle Division, and the [[26th Tank Division (Soviet Union)|26th]] and [[38th Tank Division]]s, as well as the [[210th Motorized Division]] of the 20th Mechanized Corps.{{Sfn|Glantz|2010|p = 122}} On 17 July, the corps was concentrated in the area of Horoditshe, Dubrovka and Ordat. In the morning it attacked towards [[Kopys]], but was stopped by German infantry from [[IX Army Corps (Wehrmacht)|IX Army Corps]]. By 21 July, the corps composed most of the forces defending Mogilev and was surrounded by German troops. The 20th Mechanized Corps defended Tcherniavka, Ruditsy, Ordat and Horoditshe. The 110th Rifle Division defended Horoditshe, Kniazhitsy, Pletshitsy and Mostok. The remnants of the [[137th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|137th Rifle Division]] defended near the village of Sukhari. On 23 July, the corps was forced to retreat to the line of Konstantinovka and Kamenka. Headquarters also lost contact with the 172nd Rifle Division, defending Mogilev. Under heavy attack from German troops and without resupply, the corps had retreated into the center of Mogilev by 24 July. The corps ran out of ammunition, food and fuel supplies by 25 July. Despite orders to the contrary from higher headquarters, Bakunin ordered the 61st Corps to break out of the encirclement towards [[Mstsislaw|Mstislavl]] and [[Roslavl]] on the night of 26–27 July. The 20th Mechanized Corps wound advance in the vanguard and the most combat-ready troops of the 110th Rifle Division would form the rear guard. 172nd Rifle Division commander Major General Romanov decided to break out of positions in Mogilev on his own. By this time, the remnants of the 1st Motor Rifle Division, [[161st Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|161st Rifle Division]] and other 20th Army units were in the corps positions. The wounded were left behind in the city. However, most of the 61st Rifle Corps was captured in the breakout attempt. {{Sfn|Glantz|2010|pp = 276–281}} After two days of heavy fighting and the total defeat of the corps, Bakunin ordered the remnants of the corps to move east in small groups. Bakunin personally led 140 troops of the corps out of the encirclement. The 61st Rifle Corps was disbanded on 5 August 1941, although it had ceased to exist as an organized unit during the breakout from Mogilev. == Second formation == The Corps was formed in the spring of 1943. It was part of the active army from 12 July 1943. At the time, the corps included the [[51st Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|51st]], [[62nd Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|62nd]] and [[119th Rifle Division]]s. The corps began combat on the Western Front with the 21st Army. It fought in [[Operation Suvorov]]. After fighting in the operation during the summer and early fall, the corps headquarters was transferred to the reserve.{{Cite web|url = http://yarovenkosp.ucoz.ru/publ/boji_miscevogo_znachennja_volin_1944/boji_miscevogo_znachennja_chastina_3_u_strategichnij_oboroni/3_2_2_61_j_strileckij_korpus/10-1-0-73|title = 61-й стрілецький корпус|date = 21 July 2010|access-date = 11 February 2016|website = yarovenkokosp.ucoz.ru|publisher = |last = Yarovenko|first = Sergey|language = Russian|trans-title = 61st Rifle Corps}} From April to May 1944, the corps attacked towards Orsha and Mogilev. At the beginning of May, the corps was composed of the [[134th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|134th]], [[247th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|247th]] and [[274th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|274th Rifle Divisions]]. On 22 May, corps commander Major General [[Alexander Ilyin (general)|Alexander Ilyin]] was mortally wounded when his vehicle struck a mine and died of his wounds on 28 May.{{Cite book|title = Fallen Soviet Generals: Soviet General Officers Killed in Battle, 1941–1945|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=GtdqCwAAQBAJ|publisher = Routledge|date = 2016-01-20|isbn = 978-1-135-25249-6|language = en|first = Aleksander A.|last = Maslov|page = 23}}{{Cite web|title = Biography of Major-General Aleksandr Mikhailovich Ilin – (Александр Михайлович Ильин) (1899–1944), Soviet Union|url = http://generals.dk/general/Ilin/Aleksandr_Mikhailovich/Soviet_Union.html|website = generals.dk|access-date = 2016-02-19}} Ilyin was replaced in command by Major General [[Ivan Grigoryevsky]]. The corps was stationed north of [[Volodymyr-Volynsky]] and was part of the [[69th Army (Soviet Union)|69th Army]] of the [[1st Belorussian Front]].{{Cite web|title = Григорьевский Иван Фёдорович|url = http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=10728|website = www.warheroes.ru|access-date = 2016-02-11|language = Russian|trans-title = Grigorievsky Ivan Fedorovich}} During the [[Lublin–Brest Offensive]], the corps advanced on the left flank of the [[1st Belorussian Front]], providing a link with the [[1st Belorussian Front]]'s [[3rd Guards Army (Soviet Union)|3rd Guards Army]]. On 20 July, elements of the corps crossed the [[Bug River]] in the [[Kładno|Kladno]], [[Jasienica, Wołomin County|Jasienica,]] and [[Zagurnik]] areas. These units attacked towards Lublin. On 29 July, assault battalions of the 61st and [[91st Rifle Corps]] crossed the [[Vistula]] near [[Puławy]], where they captured a bridgehead on the western bank. This bridgehead would later become known as the [[Puławy Bridgehead]]. By 1 August, the 134th Rifle Division had captured [[Bzhestse]] and had repulsed German counterattacks. The corps began to expand the bridgehead, advancing to [[Nasiluv]] and [[Janowiec]]. In January 1945, the corps broke out of the bridgehead in the [[East Prussian Offensive]]. On 14 January, assault battalions launched the offensive and broke through German lines by the end of the day. The [[11th Tank Corps]] attacked through the break in the German lines. With tank support, the 134th and 274th Rifle Divisions of the corps captured [[Radom]] on 16 January. The corps continued the offensive and crossed the [[Pilica (river)|Pilica]] and [[Warta]]. It also captured [[Tomaszów Lubelski]] and [[Jarocin]]. By the end of January, it reached the [[Oder]] north of [[Frankfurt-an-der-Oder]]. By Stavka Order No. 9 of 19 February 1945, the corps was given the honorific "Radom" for its actions in the offensive.Stavka Order No. 9, 19 February 1945 In April 1945, the corps fought in the Berlin Offensive. On 16 April, the corps went on the offensive from its bridgehead north of Frankfurt and broke through German lines. During the offensive, it reached the [[Spree]] near [[Fürstenwalde]], where large German forces were positioned. The corps then fought in the [[Battle of Halbe]] against the encircled [[9th Army (Wehrmacht)|9th Army]].{{Cite book|title = Zhukov at the Oder: The Decisive Battle for Berlin|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vrVQWxqLUaEC|publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group|date = 1996-01-01|isbn = 978-0-275-95230-3|language = en|first = Tony|last = Le Tissier}} By 25 April, the 9th Army was pushed back to [[Luckenwalde]], where it was destroyed. On 26 April, the 61st Rifle Corps captured [[Treuenbrietzen]] and advanced to the [[Elbe]] near [[Magdeburg]]. On 1 May, it linked up with American troops. An order of 29 May 1945, connected to the formation of the [[Group of Soviet Forces in Germany]], ordered the disbandment of a number of rifle corps, including the 61st.[http://militera.lib.ru/docs/da/berlin_45/16.html Stavka Order No. 11095] == Corps command == {{External media |image1=[[:ru:Файл:BakuninFA.jpg]] Major-General F.A.Bakunin |image2=[[:ru:Файл:Генерал-майор Григорьевский Иван Фёдорович и гв. полковник Власенко Илья Архипович.jpeg]] Major General I.F.Grigorievsky and Guards Colonel I.A.Vlasenko}} Command appointments within the corps were as follows: '''Commander''': * Major General F.A.Bakunin * Major General A.M. Ilyin (10 July 1943 – 28 May 1944; KIA) * Lieutenant General I.F.Grigorievsky (28 May 1944 – July 1945) '''[[political commissar|Military commissar]]''': * Brigade Commissar I.V.Voronov (KIA 26 July 1941 during the breakout) * Colonel [[Ilya Arkhipovich Vlasenko|I.A.Vlasenko]] (June 1944 – June 1945){{Cite web|title = Власенко Илья Архипович|url = http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=4986#|website = www.warheroes.ru|access-date = 2016-02-19|language = Russian|trans-title = Vlasenko Ilya Arkhipovich}} '''Chief of staff''': * Major General [[Ivan Biritchev]] (wounded 6 July 1941) * Lieutenant Colonel A.N.Koriakov * Lieutenant Colonel Asafov == References == {{reflist}} * {{Cite book|title = Barbarossa Derailed: The German Advance to Smolensk, the Encirclement Battle, and the First and Second Soviet Counteroffensives, 10 July – 24 August 1941|last = Glantz|first = David M.|publisher = Casemate|year = 2010|isbn = 978-1-906033-72-9|location = |pages = }} {{Soviet Union corps}} [[Category:Rifle corps of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1939]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1945]]
